dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, have you been following this whole Amazon-Deliveroo situation? It's, uh, quite a story.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host_B, have you been following this whole Amazon-Deliveroo situation? It's, uh, quite a story.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, Host_A, absolutely. I mean, the CMA, right? The Competition and Markets Authority, they've just dropped this initial enforcement order on Amazon's investment in Deliveroo. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, Host_A, absolutely. I mean, the C M A, right? The Competition and Markets Authority, they've just dropped this initial enforcement order on Amazon's investment in Deliveroo. It's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) issued an initial enforcement order on Friday over fears that the two companies have ceased to be distinct following a $575 million funding round into Deliveroo in May, which was led by Amazon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And it's pretty unusual, apparently, because Amazon's only a minority shareholder here. Like, they put in $575 million, which is a lot, but still. Deliveroo was last valued at two billion back in 2017.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And it's pretty unusual, apparently, because Amazon's only a minority shareholder here. Like, they put in five hundred seventy five million dollars, which is a lot, but still. Deliveroo was last valued at two billion back in twenty seventeen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The probe from the CMA is somewhat unusual given Amazon is only a minority shareholder in Deliveroo, which was last valued at $2 billion in 2017 when it raised a $482 million round.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I know! It makes you wonder, like, what are their "reasonable grounds" to believe these companies are no longer distinct? They didn't even specify, did they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I know! It makes you wonder, like, what are their reasonable grounds to believe these companies are no longer distinct? They didn't even specify, did they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, the CMA said it has reasonable grounds to believe the two companies are no longer distinct. It declined to specify what these reasonable grounds are, but theyre likely based on public information about the deal, as well as information it has received privately from Amazon and Deliveroo.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, they didn't, which is, um, a bit opaque. But they're also worried about a potential merger down the line, which could see Deliveroo customers ordering via Alexa, or, you know, it'd give Amazon a second shot at food delivery after they, like, scrapped Amazon Restaurants.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, they didn't, which is, um, a bit opaque. But they're also worried about a potential merger down the line, which could see Deliveroo customers ordering via Alexa, or, you know, it'd give Amazon a second shot at food delivery after they, like, scrapped Amazon Restaurants.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The CMA said it is also concerned that the two companies could merge at some point in the future. Closer cooperation between the two companies could see Deliveroo customers placing orders via Amazon Alexa, or a takeover would give the Seattle-based giant a second try at the food delivery business after it scrapped its rival service Amazon Restaurants in June.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's a good point. I forgot about Amazon Restaurants. But Deliveroo, though, they're huge! Like, 60,000 riders, operating in 14 countries. They just need that investment to compete with, you know, the Uber Eats of the world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's a good point. I forgot about Amazon Restaurants. But Deliveroo, though, they're huge! Like, sixty thousand riders, operating in fourteen countries. They just need that investment to compete with, you know, the Uber Eats of the world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the company now operates in 500 towns and cities in 14 countries around the world. It relies on an army of 60,000 riders to transport food from 80,000 restaurants to people's homes and offices. It is a household name in the U.K. and several other countries around the world, but it needs investment, and the deep pockets of companies like Amazon, in order to keep on growing and compete with rivals like Uber Eats.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And Amazon, of course, they're saying, "Hey, this is a minority investment. It'll expand services, benefit consumers, create jobs." All the usual stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And Amazon, of course, they're saying, Hey, this is a minority investment. It'll expand services, benefit consumers, create jobs. All the usual stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An Amazon spokesperson said: We believe this minority investment will enable Deliveroo to expand its services, benefiting consumers through increased choice and creating new jobs as more restaurants gain access to the service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] But, um, you can't ignore the wider context, can you? European regulators are really cracking down on these U.S. tech giants for, like, monopolistic tactics. Google got fined over Google Shopping, remember?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, you can't ignore the wider context, can you? European regulators are really cracking down on these U S tech giants for, like, monopolistic tactics. Google got fined over Google Shopping, remember?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, European regulators are clamping down on U.S. tech giants over allegedly monopolistic and uncompetitive tactics. For example, Google was fine recently by the European Commission for promoting its own Google Shopping service in its search results ahead of other retailers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's true. And, uh, when Amazon first announced this investment, shares in other takeaway firms, like JustEat, they just tumbled. So, the market definitely saw it as a big move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's true. And, uh, when Amazon first announced this investment, shares in other takeaway firms, like JustEat, they just tumbled. So, the market definitely saw it as a big move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When Amazon announced that it planned to invest in Deliveroo, shares in takeaway firms across Europesuch as JustEat, Takeaway.com, and Delivery Herotumbled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Deliveroo, though, they're pushing back. They're saying they've been working closely with regulators, and this investment will actually enhance competition and help restaurants grow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Deliveroo, though, they're pushing back. They're saying they've been working closely with regulators, and this investment will actually enhance competition and help restaurants grow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokesperson for Deliveroo said: Deliveroo and Amazon have been working closely with regulators to obtain regulatory approvals. There are a number of major companies within the restaurant food delivery sector and this investment will enable Deliveroo to expand, innovate and, we believe, will enhance competition. This investment will help create jobs, help restaurants to grow their businesses and will improve choice for consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they even argued that if they *didn't* get this money from Amazon and went out of business, that would actually be worse for consumers. Which, you know, is a fair point in a way.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they even argued that if they didn't get this money from Amazon and went out of business, that would actually be worse for consumers. Which, you know, is a fair point in a way.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If Deliveroo failed to raise the money from Amazon, and it went out of business as a result, then it could be argued that it would be a worse outcome for consumers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is, yeah. But an expert, Jonathan Branton, he said that while investigations into minority stakes are less common, they definitely happen. The CMA must have a reason to think there's a potential adverse effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, yeah. But an expert, Jonathan Branton, he said that while investigations into minority stakes are less common, they definitely happen. The C M A must have a reason to think there's a potential adverse effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Jonathan Branton, head of EU competition at DWF, said: Investigations into acquisitions of minority stakes are certainly less common than they are for standard acquisitions, but that is not to say they do not happen. ...the CMAs decision to open an investigations means it has reason to think there is a potential adverse effect on competition in one market or another that merits further investigation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So this "initial enforcement order" basically pauses the deal, right? And it strongly suggests they're going for a full 40-day Phase 1 investigation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. So this initial enforcement order basically pauses the deal, right? And it strongly suggests they're going for a full forty-day Phase one investigation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokeswoman for the CMA told Forbes that the initial enforcement order (IEO) has been issued to effectively pause the deal between Amazon and Deliveroo while it decides whether it needs to complete what is known as a Phase 1 investigation, which would last for 40 days. The fact that the IEO has been issued is a strong indication that a Phase 1 investigation will be carried out, she said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's what it sounds like. I mean, if it *is* blocked, though, Deliveroo would have to go back to the drawing board. Although another expert, Erin Platts, said they wouldn't have trouble finding other investors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's what it sounds like. I mean, if it is blocked, though, Deliveroo would have to go back to the drawing board. Although another expert, Erin Platts, said they wouldn't have trouble finding other investors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ultimately, if the deal is blocked, then Deliveroo would have to go back to the drawing board. Erin Platts, head of Silicon Valley Bank in EMEA, told Forbes that Deliveroo wouldnt have too much difficulty finding other investors if the CMA prevented it from accepting money from Amazon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting, isn't it? So, it's not necessarily the end of the road for Deliveroo's funding, but it certainly puts a wrench in Amazon's plans for, uh, deeper expansion into food delivery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting, isn't it? So, it's not necessarily the end of the road for Deliveroo's funding, but it certainly puts a wrench in Amazon's plans for, uh, deeper expansion into food delivery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's gonna be a really interesting one to watch unfold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's gonna be a really interesting one to watch unfold.
